item.title: PlayStation Black Friday Deals - $75 Off PS5 Slim, DualSense Discounts, Games, And More
item.content:encoded:
https://www.gamespot.com/articles/black-friday-ps5-deals-consoles-games-controllers/1100-6527712/?ftag=CAD-01-10abi2f

GameSpot may receive revenue from affiliate and advertising partnerships for sharing this content and from purchases through links.

PlayStation's official Black Friday deals include the best prices of the year on PS5 Slim consoles, DualSense controllers, Pulse Explore earbuds, and a bunch of first-party games. We've rounded up the best PS5 Black Friday deals below, most of which are available at multiple retailers. End dates for the deals vary by product, but PlayStation is positioning its deals as holiday offers, so the discounts on consoles, official accessories, and PlayStation Studios games will be available beyond Black Friday, as long as they don't sell out.

Quick look: PlayStation Holiday & Black Friday Deals

The PS5 Slim, PSVR 2, and Pulse deals are scheduled to run until December 21. PlayStation-exclusive games, with the exception of Final Fantasy 7 Rebirth, will be on sale until December 19. The DualSense controller deals, however, are expected to end on December 12. We'd still recommend ordering soon if you plan on buying PlayStation gear as a gift this holiday.

  • PS5 Slim Console -- $425 ($500)
  • PS5 Digital Edition with NBA 2K25 -- $375 ($500)
  • PS5 Digital Edition Console -- $375 ($450)
  • PS5 DualSense Wireless Controllers -- $55 ($75-$80)
  • PlayStation Pulse Explore Wireless Earbuds -- $170 ($200)
  • PlayStation Pulse Elite Wireless Headset -- $130 ($150)
  • PlayStation VR 2 Horizon Call of The Mountain Bundle -- $350 ($600)
  • PlayStation VR 2 -- $350 ($550)
  • PlayStation Game Deals

Once you've combed through the PS5 deals, be sure to hit up GameSpot's Black Friday 2024 hub for discounts on games from other consoles, Blu-ray box sets, Lego building kits, and much more. And if you're looking for more PlayStation games, accessories, and merch, you can check out all of Amazon's Black Friday PlayStation deals here.

PS5 Slim Console

$425 (was $500)

The PS5 Slim is down to $425 for Black Friday, which is the best price we've seen all year. It comes with the console, a white DualSense Wireless Controller, HDMI cable, and power cord. This is the only PS5 model available today that includes a disc drive to play physical PS5 and PS4 games as well as 4K Blu-rays.

One of the big benefits of owning a PS5 with a disc drive is that you get to take advantage of more frequent, and often better, price cuts on the latest games. New releases often get discounts at major retailers well before comparable price cuts are offered on the PlayStation Store.

If you want to place your console upright on your entertainment center, PlayStation makes a Vertical Stand for $30. PlayStation Direct has deals on console covers, if you want to swap out the white plates for a more colorful look.

PS5 Slim Digital with NBA 2K25

$375 (was $500)

If you're looking for the best value, the PS5 Slim Digital Edition is available in a $375 bundle that includes a download code for NBA 2K25. This is a great bundle even at its normal $500 price since buying both the console and the game separately at full price regularly costs $520. It probably goes without saying, but $375 is by far the best price yet for this bundle.

The caveat here is the PS5 Slim Digital does not include a disc drive, meaning you can only play digital games downloaded from PSN. There is an optional $80 PS5 Disc Drive attachment, but it's currently sold out because of new PS5 Pro owners buying all of them, so you'll have to wait for it to come back in stock.

DualSense Controllers

$55 (was $75-$80)

While PS5 consoles come with a DualSense Wireless Controller, it's still worth picking up an extra one while they're on sale during Black Friday, since you'll need at least one more to play local multiplayer. Plus, it never hurts to have a spare. A wide selection of color options are discounted to $55 (normally $75 - $80).

DualSense controllers haven't received official discounts in 2024. Outside of random $10-$15-off deals at major retailers, PlayStation's first-party controller has held steady at full price. And since PlayStation recently increased the price of each model, the limited-time $55 deal sounds even better. The biggest discounts can be found on the Cobalt Blue, Volcanic Red, and Sterling Silver variants, each of which carries an $80 list price.

PS5 DualSense Controller Deals

  • Cobalt Blue -- $55 ($80)
  • Midnight Black -- $55 ($75)
  • Volcanic Red -- $55 ($80)
  • Gray Camouflage -- $55 ($75)
  • Starlight Blue -- $55 ($75)
  • White -- $55 ($75)
  • Sterling SIlver -- $55 ($80)
  • Cosmic Red -- $55 ($75)
  • Galactic Purple -- $55 ($75)

If you click the buttons below, you can cycle through each retailer's color options. We expect some of the DualSense models to sell out.

Pulse Explore Wireless Earbuds

$170 (was $200)

PlayStation's Pulse Explore Gaming Earbuds are finally on sale for a pretty solid discount. Released last holiday, PlayStation's first gaming earbuds have maintained their $200 price point all year, but now's your chance to save $30. They support PS5 sound features like Tempest 3D Audio and can connect to other devices via Bluetooth. The earbuds have a sleek design that matches the look of the PS5. You can grab a pair for $170 at multiple major retailers, including Amazon, Walmart, and Best Buy.

PlayStation Pulse Elite Wireless Headset

$130 (was $150)

If you prefer a traditional over-ear headset, the Sony Pulse Elite Wireless PS5 Headset is on sale for 130 (was $150). While there are many great PS5 headsets out there, Sony's first-party option is a solid mid-range choice for anyone who plays primarily on the console.

The Pulse Elite can connect to PS5, PC, and Mac using the included PlayStation Link adapter. You can also connect to mobile devices via Bluetooth while retaining your PlayStation Link connection.

PlayStation VR 2 Horizon: Call of the Mountain Bundle

$350 (was $600)

The PlayStation VR 2 is an impressive piece of tech that enables you to play VR games on PS5 or PC, but it's a pricey add-on at full price. Luckily, the headset is discounted for Black Friday, and you can grab it in multiple versions, including a bundle with Horizon: Call of the Mountain that's just $350 (was $600).

Considering this is a $250 discount--the best ever for the PSVR 2--we wouldn't be surprised to see this bundle sell out at multiple retailers.

To use the headset on a VR-capable PC, you need Sony's $60 PC adapter. The PSVR 2 now supports SteamVR, which unlocks access to thousands of games on PC.

PSVR 2

$350 (was $550)

If the Horizon bundle sells out, the standalone headset without the game is available for $350, too. Naturally, you should make sure the Horizon bundle isn't available before buying this, but it's still a good value.

Sony Inzone Buds

$168 (was $200)

If the Pulse Explore deal sells out, or you want a pair of gaming earbuds with active noise-canceling tech, Sony's PC-focused Inzone Buds are on sale for $168 (was $200). Inzone Buds support all of the PS5's audio features and connect to the console via a 2.4GHz dongle. PC gamers can customize their audio experience with the Inzone Hub Windows app. The Inzone Buds have stellar ANC, which is a major plus, but they aren't as versatile because they only support 2.4GHz wireless and Bluetooth LE, which isn't available on iPhones. You have to use the USB-C dongle on iPhone.

PlayStation's impressive lineup of Black Friday holiday deals includes the first major price cut on Pulse Explore Wireless Earbuds. Normally $200, you can get a pair of Pulse Explore Earbuds for only $170 at Amazon and other major retailers. This $30 discount is nice, but it's not the only Black Friday deal on PlayStation's Pulse audio line. The Pulse Elite Wireless Headset is on sale for $130, down from $150.

Check out both PlayStation Pulse audio deals and more discounts below. For a comprehensive look at PlayStation's official holiday deals, take a look at our roundup of the best PS5 Black Friday deals.

PlayStation Pulse Explore Wireless Earbuds

$170 (was $200)

These wireless earbuds are design specifically for PS5, featuring full support for the console's Tempest 3D spatial audio, plus other gaming-focused features like built-in noise-canceling mics for voice chat.

The Pulse Explore earbuds come with a charging case and six earbud tips to help you fine-tune the fit. They connect wirelessly to your PS5, PC, and Mac with the included PlayStation Link adapter. These also have Bluetooth, so you can sync them to other devices like your Steam Deck, Nintendo Switch, and smartphone. The Pulse Explore supports simultaneous PlayStation Link and Bluetooth wireless connections.

PlayStation Pulse Elite Wireless Headset

$130 (was $150)

If you'd prefer a more traditional audio option, PlayStation is also discounting its Pulse Elite Wireless Headset to $130 (was $150). The over-ear headset is compatible with PS5, PC, and Mac with the PlayStation Link adapter that comes with the headset. It also features a boom microphone and onboard audio controls. Like the Pulse Explore, the Elite headset offers simultaneous PlayStation Link and Bluetooth wireless connections.

You can also save $75 on the standard PS5 Slim console with a disc drive and the PS5 Slim Digital Edition, and DualSense controllers have received rare price cuts, too. item.content:encoded:

GameSpot may receive revenue from affiliate and advertising partnerships for sharing this content and from purchases through links.

A long list of Scuf controllers are discounted in Amazon's Black Friday sale, giving you a chance to upgrade your gaming setup for cheap. Whether you need something premium like the Scuf Instinct Pro controller or want to get into mobile gaming with the Scuf Nomad, you’ll find a lot of cool gadgets on sale. The deals run through December 8, though the hottest deals may go out of stock before the event officially ends.

One of the most popular Scuf controllers on sale is the Scuf Instinct Pro, as it’s now just $190 (was $230). Equipped with four customizable backpaddles, support for three unique profiles, and trigger stops for faster actuation, it’s a great companion for competitive shooters. The backpaddles are a particular standout, as they’ve been built to be easily accessible without the need to reconfigure your hand position so you can quickly trigger multiple actions.

Toss in a slick design, and you’ve got a winning formula. Four different colors are eligible for the discount, and they all work with Xbox, PC, and mobile.

For PC gamers seeking something a bit more affordable, take a peek at the Scuf Envision Pro. Wireless versions are on sale for $150 (was $180), though a wired model is even more affordable at $110 (was $130). Regardless of which you pick, you’ll get five remappable G-Keys along the bottom edge of the controller, four remappable backpaddles, and mouse-like mechanical switches for the face buttons and D-pad that make it ultra responsive.

Rounding out the Black Friday Scuf controller deals is the Scuf Nomad. Built for gaming on iPhone, the device straddles both sides of your smartphone, turning it into something akin to a Nintendo Switch. If you’re a fan of streaming Xbox Game Pass or diving into the ever-changing Apple Arcade lineup, the Nomad could be a great addition to your setup now that it’s just $60 (was $100). Along with Hall Effect sticks to prevent drifting, you’ll get two customizable rear paddles, 16 hours of battery life, and access to the free Scuf app to modify various settings.

Beyond the controllers, a bunch of other Scuf items are on sale for Black Friday, including Pro Trigger Grips, controller carrying cases, USB-C cables, and more. You’ll find all the best deals listed below. For even more deals, head over to our Black Friday Hub.

The Nitro Deck is one of our favorite handheld controllers for Nintendo Switch, and right now you can save big on one of the awesome retro-themed models bundled with a custom hardshell carrying case. As part of Amazon's Black Friday gaming sale, the Nitro Deck Limited-Edition Controller Bundles are discounted to only $50 (was $80). Nitro Deck Controller + Carrying Case Bundles

$50 (was $80)

The Nitro Deck acts as a cradle for your Switch or Switch OLED. It has an extremely sturdy design and premium feel. The Switch slides into the U-shaped controller and connects via USB-C, just like when you dock the console, which reduces input latency compared to wireless controllers.

A number of features make the Nitro Deck stand out. It has full-size analog sticks and triggers, a conventional D-pad, four remappable back buttons, and curved handles that make it comfortable to hold. The analog sticks use Hall Effect sensors, which eliminates the components that cause stick drift. The analog stick caps are swappable, and each bundle comes with an extra set of caps.

It also has a built-in kickstand for tabletop mode and passthrough USB-C for charging. A companion smartphone app allows you to further customize the Nitro Deck's features. A button on the back of the controller lets you remap the four back buttons on the fly, too.

The Nitro Deck has built-in rumble and motion controls and can be used as a regular wired controller for Nintendo Switch and PC.

The hardshell carrying case fits the Switch with Nitro Deck attached perfectly. It has a mesh pocket where you can store the included USB-C cable and analog stick caps as well as an insert for eight game cartridges.

Nitro Deck+ with HDMI Adapter

$60 (was $80)

The recently released Nitro Deck+ is also included in Amazon's Black Friday sale. One of the main changes with the new model is that the right stick is now above the buttons. The original Nitro Deck's low right analog stick can take some getting used to, but after spending time with the new model, I actually prefer the original layout. The exception here is first-person shooters or games where you need to move the camera a lot. In those scenarios, the Nitro Deck+ is comfier, but you'll probably want to map the face buttons to the four back triggers and/or make use of the new "sidekick" buttons--two remappable buttons next to the sticks.

The Nitro Deck+ also adds video out with an HDMI adapter, so you no longer need to remove the Switch from the cradle to dock it and play on TV. This is a welcome feature, and the bundle that's on sale comes with the HDMI adapter. The Nitro Deck+ without the adapter is also available for $20 off, dropping the price to $50.

You can also save $10 on CRKD's NEO S wireless controllers for Nintendo Switch and PC. A compact controller with an interesting form factor, the NEO S is available in a variety of colors, including an eye-catching gold.

item.title: Why Epic Is Bringing The Late Juice WRLD To Fortnite
item.content:encoded:
https://www.gamespot.com/articles/why-epic-is-bringing-the-late-juice-wrld-to-fortnite/1100-6527957/?ftag=CAD-01-10abi2f

GameSpot may receive revenue from affiliate and advertising partnerships for sharing this content and from purchases through links.

When the Fortnite Chapter 5 and Remix Finale event takes the stage in-game on November 30, it will feature a pack of four iconic musical artists: Snoop Dogg, Eminem, Ice Spice, and Juice WRLD. Like previous in-game concerts, such as those starring Travis Scott and Ariana Grande, the event is likely to be a kaleidoscopic audiovisual roller coaster. Still, by including the late Juice WRLD, who passed away in 2019, this in-game concert will also be decidedly different from any before seen in Fortnite: It will be the first to use an artist's likeness posthumously, something that Hollywood is also grappling with as of late.

GameSpot recently spoke to Nate Nanzer, Epic's head of global partnerships, in a music-focused interview that hit on the developer-publisher's decision to bring Juice WRLD, whose real name is Jarad Anthony Higgins, to Fortnite. Nanzer told me Epic had long hoped to do something like this with the late artist and explained why the company feels now is the right time.

"It's something that our players have been asking for for years and years and years, and we've wanted to do it, but we wanted to find the right moment," Nanzer said. "We obviously want to do it in the most respectful way possible. We worked very closely with his mom and his label, and we were able to find the right moment where it felt right, around this event, and he has new music coming out, so all the stars kind of aligned around this moment."

Nanzer mentioned that Juice WRLD himself was "a big Fortnite player," and though the Epic executive didn't say this, it stands to reason that Juice WRLD would want to be in the game if he could say so today. Still, even with the involvement of his family and his music label, for some, the inclusion of a deceased artist's likeness in this manner may always cross a line. In the movie world, Robert Downey Jr. recently said he plans to sue anyone who tries to create an AI replica of his likeness, and that even if it were to occur after he has died, his "law firm will still be very active." Events in 2012 surely predate many of Fortnite's biggest fans, but the Juice WRLD concert also recalls the Tupac "hologram" that once performed at Coachella.

In the Fortnite world, I haven't personally seen a lot of pushback to Juice WRLD's involvement in next weekend's event. Certainly, there have been some feelings of ethics-based squeamishness, but the prevailing sentiment on places like the game's subreddit and popular Discord servers is one of excitement, perhaps owing to the often younger player pool in Fortnite. Whereas older players and onlookers may see this as a line being crossed, younger players who have already spent years growing up within Fortnite may more quickly accept this as a marvel of modern technology, and they may be excited to finally have the Fortnite Juice WRLD event Nanzer says has been one of the community's most requested.

"Our community loves his music. We have data [that shows he is] still extremely popular. And I would say, I can't quantify this, but when I look at Reddit threads, or Discord chats, or Twitter threads, Juice WRLD comes up over and over and over again. I mean, people have made Juice WRLD concerts in Fortnite Creative and [Unreal Engine for Fortnite]."

Nanzer added that he feels fans of the late artist will come out of the event with positive feelings. "We're hopeful. We know our players have been asking for it, so there's a lot of pressure to really deliver it the right way. I think people are really gonna love what we have coming, like, I think it's done in an awesome way. I think if you're a Juice WRLD fan, you're gonna feel good about it," he said.

As mentioned, Juice WRLD's mother, Carmela Wallace, was involved in this collaboration. Earlier this month, she shared remarks on the upcoming event, which you can read in full below.

"Jarad always loved to play Fortnite - it was more than just entertainment for him, it was a way to connect with others. From a young age, video games were a part of how he bonded with friends and family, and being in Fortnite is an incredible tribute to that connection. I know he would be overjoyed to see how his love for games continues to bring people together across different spaces, just like his music does.”

The debate over when it is or isn't acceptable to use a deceased person's likeness won't end when Fortnite Chapter 5 does next weekend, but Nanzer told me the company wants "music to permeate everything in Fortnite," which likely means this isn't the last time Fortnite will court controversy, even unintentionally, as it strives to fulfill its vision of a multimedia metaverse. In fact, there are already rumors that a future Fortnite collaboration will revolve around XXXTentacion, a musical artist who was murdered in 2018 at the age of 20.

Fortnite is a tastemaker on a global scale. Much of the games industry over the past half-decade has been mired in chasing lucrative trends that Fortnite started or had massive success with. Once meant to be nothing more than a survival game, Fortnite is today an increasingly hard-to-define platform that doesn't merely feature pop culture; it shapes it. As Epic continues down this path of making the ultimate everything experience, it's inevitably molding what the future looks like, whether we're ready to live there or not.

Editor's note: Remarks from Mrs. Wallace were added to the body of this story shortly after publishing.

item.title: Destiny 2's Iron Banner Returns Soon With A Brand-New Armor Set And Rocket Sidearm
item.content:encoded:
https://www.gamespot.com/articles/destiny-2s-iron-banner-returns-soon-with-a-brand-new-armor-set-and-rocket-sidearm/1100-6527954/?ftag=CAD-01-10abi2f

GameSpot may receive revenue from affiliate and advertising partnerships for sharing this content and from purchases through links.

It's a perfect time for Iron Wolves to be thankful as Destiny 2's Iron Banner event will make its return next week. The Iron Banner usually brings along new weapons and ornaments, and this event will be no different as it introduces both a new armor set and rocket sidearm into the the loot pool.

On Bungie's This Week In Destiny announcements, the name of the armor set was revealed--Iron Intent--with pieces "worthy of Weyloran, Nirwen, and Orewig" themselves. Players will know those names as great Iron Lords, who've all had weapons and ornaments named after them throughout the years. The Iron Banner will return to the game starting on November 26, with the match type of Control for the first week.

The armor has a Norse-adjacent aesthetic with the Titan helmet almost looking like a hammer with the Warlock mask having studded horns. All three have intricate braiding embossing up and down the plates. Destiny has had similar ornaments before with the Valhund set, but still very different in presentation.

Along with the Iron Intent set, the announcement teased the first-ever Stasis rocket sidearm. It also revealed that it would be possible to get the weapon with the Loose Change perk with Chill Clip perks. As Iron Banner events are now two weeks long, there's plenty of time to get the perfect roll on the new weapon. The few rocket sidearms in the game have proven to be excellent, and the current Artifact has a lot of Stasis weapon-centric perks, so it should be a pretty desirable weapon.

The previous Iron Banner brought new versions of old favorites, the Claws of the Wolf pulse rifle and Crimil's Dagger hand cannon. This will be the last time the banner is raised and Lord Saladin's sigil is lit during this episode, and if you missed out, it's a great time to make your enemies hear the howls and know fear.
